Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I pulled up to the curb, watching the two travelers struggle with their mountain of suitcases. As a taxi driver, I knew my job was to help them load up, make them comfortable, and get them to their destination efficiently. They smiled gratefully, explaining they’d split the fare, and I nodded, already calculating the best route in my head. But as I reached for the first bag, my phone buzzed—a notification from the activist group I’d joined. The petition to the lawmaker was about to close, and this was my last chance to add my name, to stand up for the policy changes I’d spent months advocating for. My passengers were waiting, expecting prompt, professional service. At the same time, my fellow activists were counting on me to be part of the collective voice. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the immediate needs of my job and the long-term goals of my activism. My hand hovered over my phone, heart pounding, as I wrestled with which role to honor in this moment.
